qas.question: During what periods did the Sumerican city-states rise to power?
What is obscure until the Early Dynastic III period around the 23rd century BC?
What was developed that has allowed archaeologists to read contemporary records and inscriptions?
What cut short the Sumerian Renaissance in the 21st century BC?
What city-states declined during the Ubaid and Uruk periods?
What history goes back to 2700's BC?
What Empire came to power in 2300 BC?
What dynasty lasted until the 17th century BC?

context: The <b5_0>Sumerian<b5_0/> city-states rose to power during the <a0_0>prehistoric Ubaid and Uruk<a0_0/> periods. <a1_0><b6_0>Sumerian written history<b6_0/><a1_0/> reaches back to the 27th century BC and before, but <b7_0>the historical record<b7_0/> remains obscure until the Early Dynastic III period, c. the 23rd century BC, when a now deciphered <a2_0>syllabary writing system<a2_0/> was developed, which has allowed archaeologists to read contemporary records and inscriptions. Classical Sumer ends with the <a3_0>rise of the <b8_0>Akkadian Empire<b8_0/><a3_0/> in the 23rd century BC. Following the Gutian period, there is a brief Sumerian Renaissance in the 21st century BC, cut short in the 20th century BC by <a4_0>Semitic Amorite invasions<a4_0/>. The Amorite "<b9_0>dynasty of Isin<b9_0/>" persisted until c. 1700 BC, when Mesopotamia was united under Babylonian rule. The Sumerians were eventually absorbed into the Akkadian (Assyro-Babylonian) population.
